name: chloralammonia
Reason: The compound chloralammonia (ClC(Cl)(Cl)C(N)O) has several functional groups that will affect its melting point. Using a basic aliphatic chain as a starting point (which can have a low melting point, even below room temperature for small chains), we consider the following functional group contributions: 1) Chlorine substituents (assuming they are on an aliphatic chain): Each Cl substituent can increase the melting point by around 20 due to the increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces. There are three Cl atoms, so this would be 3 * 20 = 60. 2) Amino group (-NH2 replaced with -N in this molecule): An amino group can increase the melting point through hydrogen bonding capabilities, but since it's incorporated in the structure (as -N-), its effect may be less pronounced than a free NH2 group. We might estimate this increase to be about 10. 3) Hydroxyl group (OH): A hydroxyl group strongly increases the boiling point due to hydrogen bonding but has a smaller effect on melting point. Depending on other substituents and molecular structure, the OH could increase the melting by about 10. Considering these effects, the predicted melting point would be adjusted from a base of a low value (let's say 0 for a small aliphatic chain) upward by the contributions of these groups.
Prediction: 0 (base aliphatic chain) + 60 (chlorine substituents) + 10 (amino group effect) + 10 (hydroxyl group) = 80
